dt.t: slowly {wi}relinquished{/wi} his grip on the bar

dt: {bc}to give over possession or control of {bc}{sx|yield||}

pt: {sc}relinquish{/sc} {sc}yield{/sc} {sc}resign{/sc} {sc}surrender{/sc} {sc}abandon{/sc} {sc}waive{/sc} mean to give up completely. {sc}relinquish{/sc} usually does not imply strong feeling but may suggest some regret, reluctance, or weakness.
{sc}yield{/sc} implies concession or compliance or submission to force.
{sc}resign{/sc} emphasizes voluntary relinquishment or sacrifice without struggle.
{sc}surrender{/sc} implies a giving up after a struggle to retain or resist.
{sc}abandon{/sc} stresses finality and completeness in giving up.
{sc}waive{/sc} implies conceding or forgoing with little or no compulsion.

pt.t: {it}waived{/it} the right to a trial by jury

quotes.t: The Major no sooner heard the voice, than he {qword}relinquished{/qword} Mr Dombey's arm, darted forward, took the hand of the lady in the chair and pressed it to his lips.
The feedback seems to operate on the premise that people who {qword}relinquish{/qword} the civilized art of maintaining creative cities are not to be entrusted with the risks of developing further.
In April of that year Albert Slyusar, one of the legendary figures of the Afghanistan war, had {qword}relinquished{/qword} command of 103 Guards Airborne Division.
They had turned to an open adoption after pursuing infertility treatments for 18 years, and the birth mother had agreed to {qword}relinquish{/qword} custody at the hospital.

et: Middle English {it}relinquisshen{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}relinquiss-{/it}, stem of {it}relinquir{/it}, from Latin {it}relinquere{/it} to leave behind, from {it}re-{/it} + {it}linquere{/it} to leave {ma}{mat|loan|}{/ma}
shortdef: to withdraw or retreat from : leave behind
